On Friday 16 July 2004 03:59 am, kk_oop wrote:
>  Hi.=A0 I was just reading=
 an article about a novel way of implementing
>  mock objects using an anon=
ymous inner class.=A0  The article is at: 
>
>  http://www-106.ibm.com/deve=
loperworks/library/j-mocktest.html

This is really novel.  Folks have been =
using this approach for quite some 
time.  I have used it for years, and st=
ill do in the cases where a mock 
library is too heavy-weight.

>  I find, =
though, that when I try to run the sample code in listings 5
>  and 6 throu=
gh JUnit, I get a null pointer exception.

Where?

>  So now I'm wondering =
two things:
>
>  1- Does anyone see why this code wouldn't work?

Not at fi=
rst glance.

>  2- Does this approach to Mock classes add unnecessary compl=
exity?
>  Perhaps I'd just be better off using a regular ol' derived class
=
>  instead of an anonymous inner class.=A0 The catch is that the regular
> =
 ol' derived class would need to be passed into the class being tested
>  a=
s a constructor parameter instead of being contained completely by
>  the c=
lass being tested.

As I implied before, this doesn't neccessarily add comp=
lexity.  In fact, I 
often use it to avoid the complexity of a mock framewo=
rk.  YMMV.

One thing to watch out for is duplication.  If you find yoursel=
f creating the 
same types of support classes as nested classes over and ov=
er again it's a 
sign that you need to pull that support class out into a t=
op-level (as the 
article suggests with MockTransaction).
